article_title: Big bills hit even those with insurance
article_text:
Big bills hit even those with insurance Study: Even some with health care coverage can’t pay medical bills

Photo: Houston Chronicle File Photo Increasingly, insurers have required customers to pay a larger...

Having health insurance is not always a guarantee against crippling medical debt in this country. A new study finds that 1 in 5 insured adults under age 65 still had problems paying medical bills during the past year.

article_metadata.description: Having health insurance is not always a guarantee against crippling medical debt in this country.  [...] as insurance networks narrow, customers often are surprised to find that a doctor or member of their treatment team is not in their coverage network, which leaves the patient or family on the hook for much steeper out-of-network costs.  Liz Hamel, director of public opinion and survey research at Kaiser and one of that study’s authors, said the national report is unique because it looks at not only the why of medical debt but also “the how, and it looks at the what happens after.”  Another study finding was that the cause of such medical debt is much more likely to be a one-time medical problem or short-term treatment than a long-standing illness or chronic condition.  While passage of the Affordable Care Act has helped about 15 million people in this country get insurance and ease some of the financial burden of health care, roughly 1 in 4 people overall in this country still walk a financial tightrope because of medical bills.  “People are running up credit card debt just to put food on the table,” said Karni, the Houston attorney.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam, Houston Chronicle
